events.title: Manga of the Month Club
events.description: Do you love manga, but hate in-person book discussions? Try our Manga of the Month Club!Pick up the first volume of the month's chosen series along with a review sheet. Return a completed review sheet to the Westwood Branch at any time and receive a small prize.This activity is recommended for ages 13-18 since the series are typically rated T for Teen.

events.title: Button Book Club
events.description: Do you love to read but hate deadlines? Or are you just too busy to attend traditional book club meetings? If so, our Button Book Club is perfect for you! Each month there will be a new book to read and a brand new pin to collect! How It Works Pick Your Book! Each month will feature a new Easy/Picture, Beginning Reader, Middle Grade, and Teen book. Simply pick which level you want to read and check out the book! Share Your Thoughts! Come back anytime during the month and write/draw your favorite part of the book. Get Your Pin! Each book will have it's own special, collectible pin. Participate every month to collect them all! Plus, get a free lanyard with your first pin to show them off!December Books: Easy/Picture: Just One Flake by Travis Jonker Beginning Readers: The Abominable Snowman Doesn't Roast Marshmallows by Debbie Dadey Middle Grade: Grady Jones and the Great Detective Game by Kerry Douglas DyeTeen: Beinoni by Mari Lowe

book.title: Just One Flake

events.title: Book Club: Clifton Button Book Club
events.description: Join Clifton's latest book club, The Button Book Club. Each month find a selections of books curated around themes for the Celebration of America's 250. Read the book, fill in a simple worksheet and exchange your worksheet at the desk for a button. The passive book club is open to readers of all ages!In January explore Ohio and American first. From our first President to the lunar landing, and much more. A display with a selection of books can be found on the main level of the library.

events.title: StoryWalk® with Dougherty Station and San Ramon Libraries
events.description: Get some exercise and read the latest story installed at the StoryWalk in Central Park. The winter themed story is called Except Antarctica, written and illustrated by Todd Sturgell. Follow turtle and learn about animals found on every continent except Antarctica!The San Ramon StoryWalk® is a permanent feature in San Ramon’s Central Park. The 20-station project features a new book four times a year. The San Ramon StoryWalk® project is a partnership with the Rotary Club of San Ramon, the City of San Ramon, the San Ramon Library Foundation, and the Library. The Central Park StoryWalk® begins near the Alcosta parking lot to the right of the playground, ending at the Community Center’s rear fountain. The StoryWalk Project was created by Anne Ferguson of Montpelier, VT and developed in collaboration with the Kellogg-Hubbard Library. StoryWalk is a registered service mark owned by Ms. Ferguson.

events.title: Buckeye by Patrick Ryan
events.description: Join us for a lively discussion of Buckeye by Patrick Ryan:" Buckeye is a glorious sweep of a novel, full of love and war and perilous intimacies of smalltown life (takes place in Ohio). It's funny and tender, realistic and strange. I have a feeling that with this book, Patrick Ryan is going to be everyone's favorite author!"-from Ann Patchett review ( NYT bestselling author of Tom Lake and The Dutch House)"A small-town novel of epic proportions”, this captivating story weaves the intimate lives of two midwestern families across generations, from World War II to the late twentieth century."-Tom Perrotta“I love this book with my entire heart.”—Ann Napolitano (NYT bestselling author of Hello Beautiful)"Sweeping yet intimate, rich with piercing observation and the warmth that comes from profound understanding of the human spirit, Buckeye captures the universal longing for love and for goodness." Good Reads

events.title: Inclusive Book Club with AAC (Online Event)
events.description: Hello Book Club Families, Book of the Week: Winter of the Ice Wizard by Mary Pope OsborneMerlin the magician and Morgan le Fay have disappeared, and in order to find them, Jack and Annie journey with their friends Teddy and Kathleen to the Land-Behind-the-Clouds, a frozen kingdom of ice and snow. There they must overcome their fears and solve the Ice Wizard’s riddle, because if Jack and Annie don’t complete their mission in time, Merlin and Morgan will disappear forever! This book will be read in three parts on January 15, 22, and 29. About Our Book Club: Each week, an AAC user hosts our sessions, and a librarian reads our story. After each reading, we enjoy an activity or game connected to the book, celebrating representation, creativity, and the many wonderful ways people communicate. We celebrate all forms of communication—AAC, speech, gestures, and expressions—and follow a Floortime-inspired approach that centers on meeting readers where they are and building joyful shared experiences. When applicable, a visual schedule will be emailed 24 hours before each session to help our readers follow along. Special thanks to Mary Pope Osborne and Penguin Random House for allowing us to read The Magic Tree House Merlin Missions: #4 Winter of the Ice Wizard in our virtual book club.

events.title: Little Makers Club (Ages 0-5): Winter Wonderland
events.description: This themed, literacy-based drop in program is chock full of activities to help prepare your child for school and beyond. We'll work on motor skills, literacy and counting all while playing in an enriching environment that allows for socialization and for each child to choose their own activity (matching their energy level). Ask a librarian for even more personalized recommendations!Visit the Kids Page to discover additional recommendations and resources.

events.title: Intermediate ESL Book Club - Sarah, Plain and Tall
events.description: Our intermediate ESL Book Club will read Sarah, Plain and Tall by Patricia MacLachlan. This book club is best for intermediate English learners. Students will read at home each week. Then we will meet as a group once a week to talk about the story, learn new vocabulary, and practice conversation. Book club will be led by Elaine Hilbelink. Meeting dates: January 9, 16, 23, 30; February 6, 13Meeting time: Fridays 10am - 11am Where: Literacy Table Registration is open now! Book club is limited to 10 participants. Books will be provided for registered participants to keep. Please consider your schedule and do not register if you will miss more than one meeting. Sarah, Plain and Tall description:Set in the late nineteenth century and told from young Anna's point of view, Sarah, Plain and Tall tells the story of how Sarah Elisabeth Wheaton comes from Maine to the prairie to answer Papa's advertisement for a wife and mother. Before Sarah arrives, Anna and her younger brother Caleb wait and wonder. Will Sarah be nice? Will she sing? Will she stay? This book beautifully covers themes of loss and love, loneliness and belonging, and the change and challenge of forming a new family.

events.title: The Shortlist Book Club
events.description: Discover bite-sized tales, trade great reads, and connect with fellow story lovers—whether you devour books daily or just dip into a story now and then. The Shortlist is a monthly short-story book club for adults that meets every fourth Friday from 2:00–3:00 PM. 📅 First Session: Friday, January 23, 2026 | 2:00 - 3:00 PM| Discovery Room| Foster City Library We’re kicking things off with a story swap! Bring your favorite short story—classic, quirky, mysterious, heartwarming, anything goes—and get ready to share and chat. Sign up for our mailing list to get updates, reading picks, and reminders. Come for the stories, stay for the fun—we’d love to have you!

events.title: Silent Book Club
events.description: Join our Silent Book Club at the Millbrae Library! Choose a book to read, enjoy a cup of tea, and read quietly alongside others in the library. We’ll get settled and do intros, read silently for an hour, and then share what we’re reading with others. 2:00 PM: Introductions, browse books, and quiet reading hour 3:00-3:30 PM: Share what you're reading! Light mingling optional.

events.title: Tween Book Club
events.description: Join us for our Tween Book Club! We will discuss the book of the month, have snacks, and enjoy book related activities. This month we will be reading "Amira & Hamza: The War to Save the Worlds" by Samira Ahmed. On Friday, January 9th, we will discuss chapters 1-9. On Friday, January 23rd, we will discuss chapter 10 through the end of the book. This book club is intended for children ages 8-12. Online registration is required; space is limited. Once you've received your registration confirmation email, please pick up a copy of the book of the month at the children's reference desk.

events.title: Woodside Noir Book Club
events.description: Join our mystery book club to discuss The Dry by Jane Harper. We will also talk about the author's career and other works to widen our discussion. We'll serve tea and snacks. Please ask at the front desk for a copy of the book.

book.title: The Dry

events.title: Rather Be Reading: After Hours Read-in
events.description: Do you want to join a book club but without the assigned reads and guided discussions? Join us for Rather Be Reading! Hang out with fellow readers, but read what you want to read! Enjoy an hour of silent reading, then socialize with other readers and talk books! Share your current read, your favorite reads, and other topics within the realm of what we would all rather be doing…reading! Snacks and refreshments will be provided. For adults. Inspired by Silent Book Club®

events.title: StoryWalk® with Dougherty Station and San Ramon Libraries
events.description: Get some exercise and read the latest story installed at the StoryWalk in Central Park. The winter themed story is called Except Antarctica, written and illustrated by Todd Sturgell. Follow turtle and learn about animals found on every continent except Antarctica!The San Ramon StoryWalk® is a permanent feature in San Ramon’s Central Park. The 20-station project features a new book four times a year. The San Ramon StoryWalk® project is a partnership with the Rotary Club of San Ramon, the City of San Ramon, the San Ramon Library Foundation, and the Library. The Central Park StoryWalk® begins near the Alcosta parking lot to the right of the playground, ending at the Community Center’s rear fountain. The StoryWalk Project was created by Anne Ferguson of Montpelier, VT and developed in collaboration with the Kellogg-Hubbard Library. StoryWalk is a registered service mark owned by Ms. Ferguson.

location.name: San Ramon Community Center at Central Park

events.title: Books and Bae-gels
events.description: Join us for Books and Bae-gels a romance book club that meets one Saturday each month at a coffeeshop or bakery in the Matthews area from 10am-11am. The meeting location is sent to registrants the week of the meeting via email. In January, we'll be discussing Ali Brady's Battle of the Bookstores.For a list of all the books for 2026 CLICK HERE. This program will be provided by Matthews branch library staff. Want to be notified about future events? Subscribe to our newsletter here.

location.name: Matthews
location.details: At a local coffee shop/bakery in the Matthews area.

book.title: Battle of the Bookstores

events.title: Once Upon a Crime
events.description: Join us to discuss our preselected mystery/thriller book for the month. Our book for January is Home Is Where the Bodies Are by Jeneva Rose. We will have some copies reserved for checkout; please ask at the desk. This title is also available in digital format on Libby.

events.title: Silent Book Club
events.description: Join us at Riverton Library for an hour of peaceful, quiet reading! There is no membership or required reading for this club. All are welcome to bring whatever you are currently reading or check out a book from our collection. For the first 15 minutes as everyone arrives, we will find a seat, get comfortable and chat about what we are reading, before our organizer starts our one-hour timer. Feel free to bring your own coffee, tea, or snacks. When the timer is up, you are free to keep reading or chat with other attendees. This program is presented by library staff.

events.title: Senior Book Club: ﻿The Diamond Eye
events.description: Join us in a special collaboration between Chicago Public Library and the Senior Services Division of the Department of Family and Support Services. This month we will be discussing The Diamond Eye by Kate Quinn. How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. Automatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. AccessibilityNeed sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event. Attending CPL Online EventsQuestions about attending online events? Check out our Events FAQs.

events.title: Intrigued: Northwest Book Club
events.description: Join us for a lively discussion on the book "All My Rage" by Sabaa Tahir. If you need a copy of this book, or need assistance downloading a copy to a device, please contact the library at 937-463-2665 and ask for the Northwest Library.

book.title: All My Rage

events.title: Cleveland Avenue Branch Library Book Club
events.description: Cleveland Avenue Adult Book Club will be discussing the book entitled "The First Ladies" by authors Marie Benedict and Victoria Christopher Murray. Please join us for a lively discussion. Adult program. All programs are free and open to the public.

events.title: Tutoring Club
events.description: Boost reading and math skills with our KU tutor. Register for an in-person session here. Tutoring in Reading: Pre-K–6th gradeTutoring in Math: K–9th grade This session will meet in the Children's Study Nooks. Check in at the Children's desk upon arrival. Please do not sign up for more than one session a day or two sessions a week. Sessions may be booked up to 2 weeks in advance.

events.title: Tail Wagging Readers
events.description: Ages 5–11Practice reading and build reading confidence with a warm, furry friend from Loving Paws Animal Therapy. Bring your own book or choose one at the library. No registration necessary. You will be assigned a 15-minute time slot upon arrival.

events.title: January Adult Book Discussion: The Comfort of Crows by Margaret Renkl
events.description: Join us in January for a discussion of The Comfort of Crows Follow the creatures and plants in the author's backyard over the course of a year. As we move through the seasons, from a crow spied on New Year’s Day, its resourcefulness and sense of community setting a theme for the year, to the lingering bluebirds of December, what develops is a portrait of joy and grief: joy in the ongoing pleasures of the natural world, and grief over winters that end too soon and songbirds that grow fewer and fewer. The city and the country transform a little more with each passing day, and “radiant things are bursting forth in the darkest places, in the smallest nooks and deepest cracks of the hidden world.”Books will be available to check out at the Bucktown-Wicker Park Branch circulation desk. This title may also be available on the Hoopla or Libby app. AccessibilityNeed sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.title: Spanish Book Club, La Esquina de Lectores: Luna de Agua
events.description: Join the West Town Branch Spanish book club La Esquina de Lectores, as we discuss, Water Moon by Samantha Sotto. Acompañe el Club de Libros en español, La Esquina de Lectores para dialogar sobre el título, Luna de agua de Samantha Sotto. events.title: Murphy-Wilmot Book Club
events.description: Join us to discuss what's hot in fiction and non-fiction. New members are always welcome to drop in on this informal gathering of book lovers. This month, we are reading Jess Walter's So Far Gone. From the #1 New York Times–bestselling author of Beautiful Ruins comes a lively, smart, and deliciously funny new novel in the vein of True Grit, about a reclusive journalist who is suddenly thrown into a wild, suspenseful journey to rescue his kidnapped grandchildren. “This work is a tremendous achievement: more literary and ambitious than Walter's previous popular books, with an urgency that may make it one of the strongest realist but dystopian novels of the present era.”—Library Journal

events.title: Graphic Novel Book Club: Lu and Ren’s Guide to Geozoology
events.description: Join us for another meeting of our Graphic Novel Book Club with a discussion of graphic novels. This month's title is Lu and Ren's Guide to Geozoology by Angela Hsieh. Afterward, stick around for snacks and a fun activity! Copies of the book are available at the branch or you can place a hold on this month's title for pickup at your preferred CPL location. For ages 8 to 12. How to AttendRegister by noon Friday, January 23. Chicago Public Library cannot collect personal information online from kids 0 to 13. A parent or guardian’s email address must be used to register. As a reminder, school email addresses may block external emails such as those from CPL. AccessibilityNeed sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.title: Graphic Novel Book Club: The Tea Dragon Society
events.description: Join the Myers Park Library's Graphic Novel Book Club! Each month we will read a graphic novel and meet for a discussion and for fun, themed activities! This book club is for kids ages 8-12. Registration required. This month we will be reading The Tea Dragon Society by K. O'Neill! Pick up a copy at the front desk or borrow a copy online from Libby. Synopsis:"After discovering a lost Tea Dragon in the marketplace, apprentice blacksmith Greta learns about the dying art form of Tea Dragon caretaking from the kind tea shop owners.From the award-winning author of Princess Princess Ever After comes The Tea Dragon Society, a charming all-ages book that follows the story of Greta, a blacksmith apprentice, and the people she meets as she becomes entwined in the enchanting world of tea dragons. After discovering a lost tea dragon in the marketplace, Greta learns about the dying art form of tea dragon care-taking from the kind tea shop owners, Hesekiel and Erik. As she befriends them and their shy ward, Minette, Greta sees how the craft enriches their lives - and eventually her own."

events.title: Noname Book Club
events.description: The Metropolitan Library is proud to partner with Noname Book Club to host their monthly book talks! Noname is an online/IRL community dedicated to uplifting POC voices. We do this by highlighting two books each month written by authors of color. In addition to building community with folks across the country, we also send our monthly book picks to incarcerated comrades through our Prison Program. January's Book Selection is Nervous Conditions by Tsitsi DangaremgbaImmediately hailed as a classic (Atlantic Monthly called it the best contemporary novel on colonialism to be written by an African woman), Nervous Conditions is a wrenching chronicle of the coming of age of Tambu, a teenage girl in 1960s Rhodesia, and her relationship with her British-educated cousin, Nyasha. Tambu, who yearns to be free of the constraints of her rural village, thinks her dreams have come true when her wealthy uncle offers to sponsor her education. But education at his mission school comes with a price. There she meets sophisticated Nyasha, whose rebellion against her father brings disaster. With irony and skill, Dangarembga explores the struggle of two young women to liberate themselves in a society still suffering the effects of colonization. This edition of this highly acclaimed novel is "an expression of liberation not to be missed." -- Alice Walker

events.title: Horror Book Group: Favorite Spooky Read of 2025
events.description: Share your favorite spooky read from 2025 at the first meeting of a brand new Horror Book Club.

events.title: Oh, The Horror! Book Club: The Salt Grows Heavy
events.description: Do you love strange, creepy and straight-up scary books? Then join our online horror book club led by librarians at Chicago Public Library across the city. This month's read is The Salt Grows Heavy by Cassandra Khaw. You might need to take your dictionary out for this prose filled, eerie fairytale that takes a dark twist on the Little Mermaid. "A mermaid comes to shore and weds the prince. But what the fables forget is that mermaids have teeth. And now, her daughters have devoured the kingdom and burned it to ashes. On the run, the mermaid is joined by a mysterious plague doctor with a darkness of their own. Deep in the eerie, snow-crusted forest, the pair stumble upon a village of ageless children who thirst for blood, and the three 'saints' who control them. The mermaid and her doctor must embrace the cruelest parts of their true nature if they hope to survive"-- Books are available to check out at various Chicago Public Library locations. Some titles may also be available to borrow as ebooks or eaudiobooks on the Hoopla and Libby apps. Ask a librarian for more information. Future Oh the Horror! selections February: Fledgling by Octavia Butler March: The Haunting of Hill House by Shirley Jackson AccessibilityNeed sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.title: Pineville Library Anime Club
events.description: Join us on the third Saturday of each month while we explore a variety of manga titles. Bring out your inner geek & share your fandom! Whether you're a die-hard fan or just getting started, everyone’s welcome. Bring your favorite titles, share recommendations, and make new friends! Small snacks & craft activities will be provided while we watch the first few episodes. This program will be provided by Pineville library staff and is for ages 12 to 18. How to Join Program This event takes place at the Pineville Library branch.

events.title: Adult Graphic Novel Club
events.description: Connect with fellow graphic novel lovers at our monthly book club for adults, where we explore engaging stories told through art and text. While our focus is on graphic novels for adults, we’ll also explore titles from the teen and children’s collections, because great storytelling knows no age limit! Each month, we’ll read a new graphic novel and meet to discuss themes, artwork, characters, and more. Whether you're a lifelong comics fan or just discovering the format, this club is a welcoming space for all readers. Copies of the book are available at the Wilmington-Stroop Branch Library for checkout.Please Note: Graphic novels can include intense or mature themes. We encourage participants to review content warnings ahead of time to ensure a comfortable reading experience. This month we will be reading Maus by Art Spiegelman. "Maus is a haunting tale within a tale. Vladek's harrowing story of survival is woven into the author's account of his tortured relationship with his aging father. Against the backdrop of guilt brought by survival, they stage a normal life of small arguments and unhappy visits." -library catalog description

events.title: To Mordor and Back: The Lord of the Rings Book Club
events.description: Reading To Mordor and Back Have you ever wanted to read The Lord of the Rings? maybe it's time for a re-read-or simply a love for epic fantasy adventure. Join us either in person or online this year as we travel through Tolkien's legendary world together! The LOTR Book Club will be meeting every 4th Saturday (except in Dec it will be the 3rd Saturday ) at 2pm in room N111 and on zoom.at:https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/Rs8LsrRNTPODyKOFI7jh9A Dates and reading schedule are below. Jan 24th - Fellowship of the Ring - Book One - Chapters 1-6 Feb 28th- FotR - Book One- Chapters 7-12 Mar 28th - FotR - Book Two - Chapters 1-5 Apr 25th - FotR - Book Two - Chapters 6-10 May 23rd - Two Towers - Book Three - Chapters 1-5 June 27th - Two Towers - Book Three - Chapters 6- 11 July 25th - Two Towers - Book Four - Chapters 1-5 Aug 22nd - Two Towers - Book Four - Chapters 6-10 Sept 26th - Return of the King - Book Five - Chapter 1-5 Oct 24th- RotK - Book Five - Chapters 6-10 Nov 28th - Rotk - Book Six - Chapters 1-4 Dec 19th- Rotk - Book Six - Chapters 5 - 9

events.title: Kids Reading Club
events.description: The Kids Reading Club is for elementary students who are new to reading! We will talk about books, practice reading, and sometimes have special guests. The Kids Reading Club meets on the fourth Saturday of the month at 1pm for one hour. The book is chosen and handed out at the previous month's meeting. Limited copies of the book are available at Benson Branch.Parents/caregivers must remain with their child(ren) for the duration of the program. All Omaha Public Library locations are wheelchair accessible. Need sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please email Nancy Novotny at NNovotny@omahalibrary.org to request accommodation. Requests must be made at least five business days before the activity or event.

events.title: Páginas y Pláticas
events.description: ¡Únete al club de lectura en español, Páginas y Pláticas! Nos reunimos el cuarto sábado de cada mes en la sucursal Willa Cather para hablar sobre el libro del mes y compartir buenas historias. ¡Mira lo que estamos leyendo y reserva los próximos títulos aquí! Copias limitadas del libro estarán disponibles en la sucursal. ¡Todos son bienvenidos! Todas las sucursales de la Biblioteca Pública de Omaha son accesibles para personas en silla de ruedas. ¿Necesita interpretación en lenguaje de señas u otro tipo de asistencia para accesibilidad en este evento? Por favor, envíe un correo electrónico a Nancy Novotny a NNovotny@omahalibrary.org para solicitar adaptaciones. Las solicitudes deben hacerse al menos cinco días hábiles antes de la actividad o evento.

events.title: Steamy Reads: Romance Book Club
events.description: Ready for a little heat? Dive into romance novels that range from sweet to sizzling. This month's selection is "The Seven Year Slip" by Ashley Poston. Available as an eBook and audiobook in the cloudLibrary app.

events.title: Stories Told in Panels: PreTeen Graphic Novel Club
events.description: Join us for Stories Told in Panels; the graphic novel book club for preteens! In January, we will be discussing Angelica and the Bear Prince by Trung Le Nguyen.Angelica was the girl who could do it all—until suddenly, she couldn’t. Burnout hit hard. Now, after some very low moments, she’s ready to get her life back together, thanks to her friends, and one very surprising source of comfort. A bear. Peri is the mascot of the local theater. He’s been sending Angelica supportive messages from his social. They’ve become friends, and Angelica might even have . . . a crush? Determined to find the human behind the bear costume, Angelica gets an internship at the theater. She might never go back to being the girl who can do everything, but perhaps she is becoming the girl who can magically have it all. Link to the book in the library’s catalog: https://cmlibrary.bibliocommon...It is also available as an Ebook through the Libby app! Information about this Group The Stories in Panels: Preteen Graphic Novel Club meets once per month to discuss middle grade graphic novel titles.This program will be provided by Steele Creek library staff and is recommended for preteens ages 10 and up.This program will take place indoors at the Steele Creek library.

events.title: Adult Book Discussion: Six Days to Live with Author Lisa Dodson
events.description: Join Chi-Town Reading Circle at Chicago Public Library’s Whitney M. Young, Jr. Branch for a discussion of Six Days to Live with Lisa Dodson and her readers. Copies are available at the Whitney M. Young, Jr. circulation desk. Also, she will inform readers about her future projects. Lisa Dodson is an award‑winning, national and Amazon #1 bestselling author of more than nineteen books spanning clean romance, romantic suspense, inspirational, and Christian fiction. A DC native living in Raleigh, she’s known for multicultural casts, vivid storytelling, and closed‑door love stories with high emotional stakes. By day she’s a tech‑firm business development director; by night, she writes Clean Romances with Heart, Hope, and Happily‑Ever‑Afters. Another book by her in CPL's catalog is The Bodyguard's Deadly Mission. How to Attend This event is available in person and online. Attend in person at the Whitney M. Young, Jr. Branch, 415 E 79th St, Chicago, IL 60619 Attend online via ZoomOnly one registration per household is needed. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 48 hours before the meeting. Questions about attending online events? Check out our Events FAQs. Accessibility Need sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event. Photo Provided by Lisa Dodson

events.title: RP Mystery Group: The Sunday Philosophy Club
events.description: Join the Rogers Park Branch Mystery Group as we read Alexander McCall Smith's The Sunday Philosophy Club. Isabel Dalhousie is fond of problems, and sometimes she becomes interested in problems that are, quite frankly, none of her business. This may be the case when Isabel sees a young man plunge to his death from the upper circle of a concert hall in Edinburgh. Despite the advice of her housekeeper, Grace, who has been raised in the values of traditional Edinburgh, and her niece, Cat, who, if you ask Isabel, is dating the wrong man, Isabel is determined to find the truth-if indeed there is one-behind the man's death. The resulting moral labyrinth might have stymied even Kant. And then there is the unsatisfactory turn of events in Cat's love life that must be attended to.Books are available at the Rogers Park Branch Reference Desk. AccessibilityNeed sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.description: Join Harold Washington Library Center for a discussion of The Plotters by Un-Su Kim."A fantastical crime novel set in an alternate Seoul where assassination guilds compete for market dominance." In Translation Book Club meets monthly on the 3rd or 4th Saturday of each month, holidays permitting. All selections are books that have been translated to English from another language.You may pick up a copy of The Plotters one month in advance at the Popular Library Reference Desk on the 1st floor of the Harold Washington Library Center. events.title: Bilingual Family Read-Aloud Book Club
events.description: Kids and their caregivers are invited to join our Bilingual Family Read-Aloud Book Club! This program is perfect for families who want to practice reading in English or another language. The library will provide books in English and additional languages, giving families the opportunity to read together in whichever language they’re most comfortable. Enjoy taking turns reading with your child and sharing conversations about your favorite stories. Registration is preferred but not required. Niños y sus cuidadores están invitados a unirse a nuestro Club de Lectura Familiar Bilingüe! Este programa es ideal para familias que desean practicar la lectura en inglés o en otro idioma. La biblioteca tendra libros en inglés y en otros idiomas, brindando a las familias la oportunidad de leer juntos en el idioma con el que se sientan más cómodas. Disfruten leer en turnos con sus hijos y compartan conversaciones sobre sus historias favoritas. Se recomienda inscribirse, pero no es requerido. Want to be notified about future events? Subscribe to our newsletter here.

events.title: Read Black Book Club
events.description: Pima County Public Library’s Kindred Team invites you to Read Black! Join us as we further the conversation on Black literature, history, and culture. This monthly book club will include alternating months of conversations about books focused on the Black experience, both fictional and real. On odd months, we'll read a book together, with a facilitated discussion guided by a member of the Kindred team. On even months, attendees will come ready to discuss one or more books by and about Black folks, and a list of books discussed will be made for the library website. Our January book: Hell of A Book This meeting will be held via Zoom. Please register in order to receive login information shortly before the meeting begins.

events.title: Late-Identified Neurodivergent Book Club
events.description: This book club welcomes all neurotypes. Whether you’re self-identified, officially diagnosed, questioning, or an ally, we would love to have you! The club has a special eye toward those discovering their ADHD or autism in adulthood, but we celebrate all neurodiversity. Join us as we explore a range of books, sharing insights, experiences, and perspectives in an understanding and inclusive environment. Whether you’re seeking information, social connections, or simply the joy of reading and sharing with like-minded individuals, our club is an open space for everyone.This month we will discuss Turtles All the Way Down by John Green. Here are some content warnings about this title from The StoryGraph: Graphic: Mental illness, Panic attacks/disorders, Self harm Moderate: Death of parent, Car accident, Grief Minor: Vomit, Suicidal thoughts We meet monthly on 4th Saturdays at the Downtown Main Library. Newcomers are always welcome! About the space and the event: Getting to the event: The Main Library is easily accessible by public transit, with the streetcar and several bus lines stopping nearby. A bike rack is available on the east side of Vine Street, between 8th and 9th Streets. Paid street parking and nearby parking lots are also available. Accessible parking can be found in the gated lot next to our North Building on the north side of 9th Street, just west of Walnut Street. To enter this lot, press the button outside the gate to speak with a staff member. Please be prepared to show your placard.Navigating the building: The library is a large, busy, urban public building. If you are sensitive to noise, you may want to bring noise-canceling headphones or earplugs. The building is wheelchair accessible, with both stairs and elevators available to reach the 3rd floor. Staff members are available to assist if you need help finding the room.Meeting location: The event will take place in the South Building, Room 3E, a spacious meeting room on the 3rd floor. The room features ample seating and natural lighting, supplemented by overhead LED lighting.Ventilation: The room is well-ventilated and equipped with air conditioning.Arrival: The staff facilitator will open the room 30 minutes early. You are welcome to arrive early to check out the space, get settled, and ask any questions. The facilitator will begin with a brief introduction, invite participants to introduce themselves if they wish, and provide an overview of the session.Discussion: The book discussion will last approximately one hour.Wrap-up: After the discussion, participants are welcome to stay for socializing if they so choose. If you would like to visit the space in advance of the event or have any questions, please email michelle.thompson@chpl.org.

events.title: Shelf-Indulgence Book Club
events.description: Join us at Southeast for a thrilling book discussion. Pick up a book at the Southeast branch or download the ebook or audiobook on the Libby app. Our book selected for January is The Last Murder at the End of the World by Stuart Turton.

book.title: The Last Murder at the End of the World

events.title: Chinatown Cultural Reads: The Family Chao by Lan Samantha Chang
events.description: Come read with your community! Teens and adults of all ages are invited to join us for a monthly discussion of a book related to the Chinese and Chinese American experience. This month's discussion is: The Family Chao by Lan Samantha Chang. "An acclaimed storyteller returns with "a gorgeous and gripping literary mystery" that explores "family, betrayal, passion, race, culture and the American Dream" (Jean Kwok). The residents of Haven, Wisconsin have dined on the Fine Chao restaurant's delicious Americanized Chinese food for thirty-five years, happy to ignore any unsavory whispers about the family owners. But when brash, charismatic, and tyrannical patriarch Leo Chao is found dead-presumed murdered-his sons find they've drawn the exacting gaze of the entire town. The Family Chao offers a kaleidoscopic, highly entertaining portrait of a Chinese American family grappling with the dark undercurrents of a seemingly pleasant small town." Pick up a copy of the book at the Circulation Desk. Space is limited. Registration is required. For teens and adults ages 13 and up. AccessibilityNeed sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.title: Adult Book Club
events.description: Join us as we discuss our title for the month. It will be a great opportunity to meet and greet with other customers while discussing our title of the month.

events.title: An Afternoon with the Author: Join Us for a Book Discussion on *Done in the Dark*
events.description: We're thrilled to welcome the talented author of *Done in the Dark* as she leads an engaging discussion about her captivating book. Whether you're a longtime fan or new to her work, this is an excellent opportunity to dive deep into the story and hear insights directly from the author. Don't miss out on complimentary refreshments as you connect with fellow book lovers in the community! You can find *Done in the Dark* available as an ebook on Hoopla, or visit the Elmhurst library to grab a free copy—available while supplies last. Mark your calendars and prepare for an inspiring afternoon of literature and conversation!

events.title: Adult Book Discussion: Yellowface by Rebecca R.F. Kuang
events.description: Come join us for a lively book discussion!"Authors June Hayward and Athena Liu were supposed to be twin rising stars. But Athena's a literary darling; June Hayward is literally nobody. Who wants stories about basic white girls?, June thinks. So when June witnesses Athena's death in a freak accident, she acts on impulse: she steals Athena's just-finished masterpiece, an experimental novel about the unsung contributions of Chinese laborers during World War I. So what if June edits Athena's novel and sends it to her agent as her own work? So what if she lets her new publisher rebrand her as Juniper Song--complete with an ambiguously ethnic author photo? Doesn't this piece of history deserve to be told, whoever the teller? The subsequent month's book club selection will be available after our book talk. events.title: Book Clubs of EPL: Normal People
events.description: Love reading? Love to talk about books you've read? Come join us for lively discussions on all types of fiction and non-fiction. We'll feature different titles and authors each month. Come and share your impressions, thoughts and interpretations of a book we have all read. This month we will be reading Normal People by Sally Rooney."Connell Waldron is one of the most popular boys in his small-town high school--he is a star of the football team, an excellent student, and never wanting for attention from girls. The one thing he doesn't have is money. Marianne Sheridan, a classmate of Connell's, has the opposite problem. Marianne is plain-looking, odd, and stubborn, and while her family is well-off, she has no friends to speak of. There is, however, a deep and undeniable connection between the two teenagers, one that develops into a secret relationship. Everything changes when both Connell and Marianne are accepted to Trinity College. Suddenly Marianne is well-liked and elegant, holding court with her intellectual friends while Connell hangs at the sidelines, not quite as fluent in language of the elite. Throughout their years at university, Marianne and Connell circle each other, falling in and out of romance but never straying far from where they started. And as Marianne experiments with an increasingly dangerous string of boyfriends, Connell must decide how far he is willing to go to save his oldest friend."Please login to your account with your library card and then register to reserve a copy of the book.

events.title: Metro Year of the Book Club
events.description: 2026 is the Year of the Book at your Fulton County Library System! Join the new Metro Year of the Book Club to read all of the monthly featured titles we are recommending this year, followed by a lively discussion of the book at the end of the month. We can't wait to meet you at the library! January's selection is The Library Book by Susan Orlean:In this lively and multilayered portrait of the Los Angeles Public Library by Orlean (The Orchid Thief), the author describes a source as "electrified by everything he told me about the library." The same can be said for Orlean, whose enthusiasm and affection for the nearly 150-year-old institution is contagious. As in previous books and essays, Orlean assembles a panoramic profile from an array of fascinating details, from the library's earliest days as a reading room to its current thriving community presence as a provider of English classes, sheet -music for orchestras, services for the homeless, and more, including sketches of its charismatic-sometimes eccentric--directors, staff, and patrons. This sweeping, cheerful history revolves around a singular, terrible event: the 1986 fire that ravaged the Central Library, destroying some 400,000 books. Orlean's affecting account of the tragedy and its painful aftermath, as well as the many people it touched, points to a suspect who was never indicted. But the overall tone is warm and engaging, offering a love letter to libraries everywhere. VERDICT Orlean's fans, library lovers, and readers of eclectic nonfiction will enjoy this entertaining, informative account.

events.title: Adult Book Discussion: Poets Square: A Memoir in Thirty Cats
events.description: Join us for a discussion of the delightful, award-winning 2025 memoir, Poets Square."When Courtney Gustafson moved into a rental house in the Poets Square neighborhood of Tucson, Arizona, she didn't know that the property came with thirty feral cats. Focused only on her own survival--in a new relationship, during a pandemic, with poor mental health and a job that didn't pay enough--Courtney was reluctant to spend any of her own time or money caring for the wayward animals. But the cats--their pleading eyes, their ribs showing, the new kittens born in the driveway--didn't give her a choice. She had no idea about the grief and hardship of animal rescue, the staggering size of the problem in neighborhoods across the country. And she couldn't have imagined how that struggle--towards an ethics of care, of individuals trying their best amidst spectacularly failing systems--would help pierce a darkness she'd wrestled for with much of her life."AccessibilityNeed sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.title: Literary Lounge Book Club: Fantasy
events.description: Getting back into reading? Want to try new genres? Join the Chinatown Branch for our Literary Lounge Book Club! Each month, we will explore a new genre and discuss not only the book, but also elements of the genre. This month's theme will be: Fantasy. In Matt Haig's The Midnight Library, "Somewhere out beyond the edge of the universe, there is a library that contains an infinite number of books, each one the story of another reality. One tells the story of your life as it is, along with another book for the other life you could have lived if you had made a different choice at any point in your life. While we all wonder how our lives might have been, what if you had the chance to go to the library and see for yourself? Would any of these other lives truly be better?" Pick up a copy of the book at the Circulation Desk. Space is limited. Registration is required. For adults 18 and up. AccessibilityNeed sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.title: Book Discussion: The Scammer
events.description: Join us as we dive into The Scammer by Tiffany D. Jackson. A razor-sharp dive into deception, desperation, and power. In a world where trust is weaponized and survival demands sacrifice, the line between victim and predator all but disappears. This provocative novel forces readers to confront an unsettling question: When the system is broken, is scamming a sin—or a strategy? Expect tension, moral reckoning, and fearless conversation.How to Attend This event is available in person and online. Attend in person at the South Chicago Branch 9055 S. Houston. Attend online via ZoomOnly one registration per household is needed. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. Questions about attending online events? Check out our Events FAQs. Accessibility Need sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.description: Join the Rogers Park Branch as we read and discuss K. Woodman-Maynard's graphic adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Great Gatsby.Nick Carraway moves next door to Jay Gatsby in West Egg, Long Island. Gatsby had once loved beautiful, spoiled Daisy, then lost her to rich boy Tom Buchanan. Now, mysteriously wealthy, he is ready to risk everything to woo her back, and Nick gets caught up in the mess...Books are available at the Rogers Park Reference Desk. Accessibility Need sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.title: Adult Book Discussion: Phantom of the Opera
events.description: Join the Canaryville Branch Adult Book Club for a discussion of The Phantom of the Opera by Gaston Leroux. “Rumors abound that a ghost stalks the dark passages and cellars of the Paris Opera House. No one has actually seen this Phantom, but Christine Daaé, a beautiful and talented young singer, has heard his voice. He is her “Angel of Music,” coaching her to sing as she never could before. When the handsome Viscount begins to court Christine, the mysterious Phantom-consumed by jealousy-rises up to seek revenge." -Penguin Publishing This discussion will coincide with Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical adaptation of Phantom of the Opera making a triumphant return to Chicago (December 11th-February 1st at the Cadillac Palace Theater). Come into the branch, grab a copy of the book, and then join us for a lively discussion! AccessibilityNeed sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.title: Adult Book Discussion: The Family Upstairs by Lisa Jewell
events.description: Please join us for a discussion of The Family Upstairs by Lisa Jewell."Soon after her twenty-fifth birthday, Libby Jones returns home from work to find the letter she's been waiting her entire life. She soon learns not only the identity of her birth parents, but also that she is the sole inheritor of the abandoned mansion on the banks of the Thames in London's fashionable Chelsea neighborhood, worth millions. Everything in Libby's life is about to change. But what she can't possibly know is that others have been waiting for this day as well--and she is on a collision course to meet them."AccessibilityNeed sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.title: True Crime Podcast Discussion Club
events.description: Do you love true crime? Join us for a true crime podcast discussion club! Twice a month, we’ll meet virtually to discuss a few episodes of a true crime podcast, share our favorites, and get recommendations. Over the next few weeks, we'll be listening to Season 2 of Guru: Don't Cross Kat. When a woman tries to rescue her best friend from the grip of a modern-day guru, she unwittingly crosses paths with Kat—a collision that changes everything. You can listen via the link above or on Apple or Spotify. Here's what to listen to before we meet: January 12: Episode 1 "The Witches Who Work For You" and 2 "Searching for Desirre"January 26: Episode 3 "The Voice" and 4 "Inside Kat's House"February 9: Episode 5 "Closing In" and 6 "After the Spell"February 23: Episode 7 "The One Who Got Away" and 8 "The Making of a Beauty Queen" This program is for adults 18 and up due to mature themes, violence, and adult language that may be in the podcasts. These podcasts may contain triggering themes and may feature content warnings. If you listen to episodes beyond the week's assigned episodes, please do not reveal details during our discussion to prevent spoilers! This program will be provided by North County and Matthews library staff. How to Join an Online Program This event takes place on Zoom. Please register by 5:00 p.m. the day before the event. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting.Want to be notified about future events? Subscribe to our newsletter here.New to using Zoom? Check out this video to help you get started: Looking for more technology resources? Check out this list!

events.title: Strange New Worlds
events.description: Join us usually, but not always, on the third Monday of each month at 7:00 pm for the Strange New Worlds book club! This month's book is The Cautious Traveller's Guide to the Wastelands by Sarah Brooks. From the Publisher: "For fans of Piranesi and The Midnight Library, a stunning historical fantasy novel set on a grand express train, about a group of passengers on a dangerous journey across a magical landscape. It is said there is a price that every passenger must pay. A price beyond the cost of a ticket. There is only one way to travel across the Wastelands: on the Trans-Siberian Express, a train as famous for its luxury as for its danger. The train is never short of passengers, eager to catch sight of Wastelands creatures more miraculous and terrifying than anything they could imagine. But on the train's last journey, something went horribly wrong, though no one seems to remember what exactly happened. Not even Zhang Weiwei, who has spent her life onboard and thought she knew all of the train's secrets. Now, the train is about to embark again, with a new set of passengers. Among them are Marya Petrovna, a grieving woman with a borrowed name; Henry Grey, a disgraced naturalist looking for redemption; and Elena, a beguiling stowaway with a powerful connection to the Wastelands itself. Weiwei knows she should report Elena, but she can't help but be drawn to her. As the girls begin a forbidden friendship, there are warning signs that the rules of the Wastelands are changing, and the train might once again be imperiled. Can the passengers trust each other, as the wildness outside threatens to consume them all?" This program will be provided by Charlotte Mecklenburg Library staff and our wonderful Volunteer leader. Information about this Group The Strange New Worlds Book Club meets on the 3rd Monday of the month to discuss Science Fiction and Fantasy titles. How to Join an Online ProgramThis event will take place Zoom and in person. Please call 704-416-4000 for more information. Please register by 10:00 am the day of the event. You’ll receive an email with a secure Zoom link with a reminder about the meeting.Looking for more technology resources? Check out this list!

events.title: *Hybrid* Science Fiction Book Club
events.description: If you enjoy Science Fiction, then this is the book club for you! The Science Fiction Book Club meets at it's new day and time, on the 4th Monday of every month, at the Pearl Avenue Library, and on Zoom (as a hybrid meeting), starting at 4:00 p.m. Be sure to register to receive the zoom link, otherwise, we will see you at the library! Monday, January 26, 4:00 p.m. - Continuum: French Science Fiction Short Stories, ed. by Annabelle Dolidon, with Tessa Sermet.This unique collection of newly translated short stories offers a taste of classic and contemporary French science fiction to English-language readers. These stories cover a range of fascinating topics including simulated reality, speciesism, ecology, and transhumanism-all while exploring universal themes of belonging, death, and identity. Some of the authors featured in this anthology, like Julia Verlanger, Sylvie Denis, or Jean-Claude Dunyach, have shaped the history of French science fiction after World War II. Curated by Annabelle Dolidon and Tessa Sermet, French language and literature professors who share a love for the genre, these nine stories showcase some of the brilliant mid- to late twentieth century and twentieth century French contributions to science fiction. Dolidon and Sermet provide illuminating expansions that accompany each tale and fascinating insights into the evolution of French and American science fiction. This anthology is a great opportunity to discover French sci-fi in English translation for fans or readers new to the genre.Monday, February, 23, 2026, 4:00 p.m. TBDMonday, March 23, 2026, 4:00 p.m. TBDMonday, April 27, 2026, 4:00 p.m. TBDMonday, May 18, 2026, 4:00 p.m. TBDMonday, June 22, 2026, 4:00 p.m. TBDMonday, July 27, 2026, 4:00 p.m. TBDMonday, August 24, 2026, 4:00 p.m. TBDMonday, September 28, 2026, 4:00 p.m. TBDMonday, October 26, 2026, 4:00 p.m. TBDMonday, November 23, 2026, 4:00 p.m. TBDMonday, December 14, 2026, 4:00 p.m. TBD ADA Accommodation Requests

events.title: Tea & Robots Book Club
events.description: Have an appetite for science fiction but don't have time to delve into another space opera? Join us every third Monday of the month to discuss the novellas and short story collections of award-winning sci-fi authors. Through this Spring's offerings of stories, readers will explore a range of topics, from androids to first contact, and from post-apocalyptic to Afrofuturism. Registered participants are welcome to pick up their copies of this month’s book at Divoll.For our very first novella, we’re reading All Systems Red, the first installment of Martha Wells’ Murderbot Diaries. After overriding its control module, Murderbot becomes a free agent. Not knowing what to do with its newly found freewill–beyond binge watching its favorite show–Murderbot pretends to be a security unit for a group of hippy space scientists. But keeping them alive on an alien planet proves to be harder than expected.For accessibility accommodations, please call 314-241-2288.

events.title: 星期一下午:西游记 (读书会)
events.description: A book club dedicated to "Journey to the West," the classic Chinese fiction. This club is designed for children who are fans of the story and is conducted entirely in Mandarin Chinese. The event is organized by dedicated teen volunteers from Lynbrook High School.小朋友们，你们听说过《西游记》吗？ 这是中国最有名的神话故事之一，讲述了一段惊险又有趣的旅程。在这个故事里，有聪明勇敢的孙悟空、善良慈悲的唐僧、憨厚搞笑的猪八戒，还有忠诚可靠的沙和尚。他们一路上经历了许多危险和考验，但靠着智慧和团结，成功完成了任务。这次旅程不仅是他们追寻经书的故事，更是一场关于勇气、坚持和成长的冒险！更多有关 美猴王系列丛书. 免费的亲子中文活動. 座位数量有限. 门票将在故事时间开始前 30 分钟在询问处领取。 圖書館中文资源: 大人最新中文书, 中文電子書, 非小說類電子書 (Overdrive) 有歡迎大家一起來借閱電子書. Overdirve平台: 小朋友的中文電子書, 大朋友的中文電子小說, 大朋友的非小說類的電子書籍. Hoopla平台: 中文有聲書籍 美国残疾人法案(ADA)申请提供协助 5/25/2026

events.title: Food For Thought: A Culinary Book Club
events.description: Indulge in your passion for literature and cuisine at a unique book club where we combine the love of reading with the love of food! Each month, we'll dive into a new book and eat delicious snacks inspired by its themes. From fiction to non-fiction, our diverse selection of books will spark lively discussions as we share our impressions, thoughts, and interpretations. Don't miss out on this opportunity to bond with fellow book-lovers over a shared love of literature and food.This month we will be reading Maisie Dobbs by Jacqueline Winspear."Maisie Dobbs, Psychologist and Investigator, began her working life at the age of thirteen as a servant in a Belgravia mansion, only to be discovered reading in the library by her employer, Lady Rowan Compton. Fearing dismissal, Maisie is shocked when she discovers that her thirst for education is to be supported by Lady Rowan and a family friend, Dr. Maurice Blanche. But The Great War intervenes in Maisie’s plans, and soon after commencement of her studies at Girton College, Cambridge, Maisie enlists for nursing service overseas.Years later, in 1929, having apprenticed to the renowned Maurice Blanche, a man revered for his work with Scotland Yard, Maisie sets up her own business. Her first assignment, a seemingly tedious inquiry involving a case of suspected infidelity, takes her not only on the trail of a killer, but back to the war she had tried so hard to forget."We will be making Oatmeal Brown Betties to accompany our discussion of the book. NOTE: Registration is required and there is a $5 charge for this class. Payment can be made via Eventbrite. A link will be sent to the email address you provide when you complete the registration process on this page.

events.title: Book Clubs of EPL: Vera Wong's Unsolicited Advice for Murder
events.description: Love reading? Love to talk about books you've read? Join our book club for spirited discussions on a wide range of fiction and non-fiction. Each month we'll tackle a new title. Whether you loved it, loathed it, or left it unfinished, we want to hear your take. Come share your impressions and connect with fellow readers! This week we will be reading Vera Wong's Unsolicited Advice for Murder by Jesse Q. Sutanto. "Knives Out meets Kim's Convenience in this captivating mystery by Jesse Q. Sutanto, bestselling author of Dial A for Aunties. Vera Wong is a lonely little old lady-ah, lady of a certain age-who lives above her forgotten tea shop in the middle of San Francisco's Chinatown. Despite living alone, Vera is not needy, oh no. She likes nothing more than sipping on a good cup of Wulong and doing some healthy detective work on the Internet about what her college-aged son is up to. Then one morning, Vera trudges downstairs to find a curious thing-a dead man in the middle of her tea shop. In his outstretched hand, a flash drive. Vera doesn't know what comes over her, but after calling the cops like any good citizen would, she sort of . . . swipes the flash drive from the body and tucks it safely into the pocket of her apron. Why? Because Vera is sure she would do a better job than the police possibly could, because nobody sniffs out a wrongdoing quite like a suspicious Chinese mother with time on her hands. Vera knows the killer will be back for the flash drive; all she has to do is watch the increasing number of customers at her shop and figure out which one among them is the killer. What Vera does not expect is to form friendships with her customers and start to care for each and every one of them. As a protective mother hen, will she end up having to give one of her newfound chicks to the police?"--Provided by publisher.

book.title: Jesse Q. Sutanto

events.title: Manchester Book Group
events.description: Pick up the next book club selection at the Manchester library service desk following the previous month's meeting on the 3rd Monday of the month. This month we are discussing: A Gentleman in Moscow by Amor TowlesFrom the Publisher:In 1922, Count Alexander Rostov is deemed an unrepentant aristocrat by a Bolshevik tribunal, and is sentenced to house arrest in the Metropol, a grand hotel across the street from the Kremlin. Rostov, an indomitable man of erudition and wit, has never worked a day in his life, and must now live in an attic room while some of the most tumultuous decades in Russian history are unfolding outside the hotel’s doors. Unexpectedly, his reduced circumstances provide him entry into a much larger world of emotional discovery.Brimming with humor, a glittering cast of characters, and one beautifully rendered scene after another, this singular novel casts a spell as it relates the count’s endeavor to gain a deeper understanding of what it means to be a man of purpose.

events.title: Virtual True Crime Book Club - Yellow Bird
events.description: Love watching true crime documentaries and tv shows? Can't get enough of true crime podcasts? This is a monthly book group focused on reading and discussing True Crime. Join us on Zoom to discuss Yellow Bird: Oil, Murder, and a Woman's Search for Justice in Indian Country by Sierra Crane Murdoch. Yellow Bird"When Lissa Yellow Bird was released from prison in 2009, she found her home, the Fort Berthold Indian Reservation in North Dakota, transformed by the Bakken oil boom. In her absence, the landscape had been altered beyond recognition, her tribal government swayed by corporate interests, and her community burdened by a surge in violence and addiction. Three years later, when Lissa learned that a young white oil worker, Kristopher “KC” Clarke, had disappeared from his reservation worksite, she became particularly concerned. No one knew where Clarke had gone, and few people were actively looking for him. Yellow Bird traces Lissa’s steps as she obsessively hunts for clues to Clarke’s disappearance. She navigates two worlds—that of her own tribe, changed by its newfound wealth, and that of the non-Native oilmen, down on their luck, who have come to find work on the heels of the economic recession. Her pursuit of Clarke is also a pursuit of redemption, as Lissa atones for her own crimes and reckons with generations of trauma. Yellow Bird is an exquisitely written, masterfully reported story about a search for justice and a remarkable portrait of a complex woman who is smart, funny, eloquent, compassionate, and—when it serves her cause—manipulative. Drawing on eight years of immersive investigation, Sierra Crane Murdoch has produced a profound examination of the legacy of systematic violence inflicted on a tribal nation and a tale of extraordinary healing." -From the publisher

It's the first in the Cypress Cove Mystery series, blending wine country charm with amateur sleuthing and danger.

events.title: History and Historical Fiction Book Club
events.description: Join us on the 4th Wednesday of each month at 12:00 Noon for The History and Historical Fiction Book Club! This month we'll be discussing The Paris Express by Emma Donoghue. From Booklist: "On the morning of October 22, 1895, the Paris Express leaves the town of Granville in Normandy for its seven-hour, ten-minute trip to the capital. Unbeknownst to its many passengers, the train is hurtling toward a crashing halt. Donoghue (Learned by Heart, 2023) superbly portrays the lead-up to the Montparnasse derailment, a disaster memorialized in astounding photographs, as experienced by travelers of diverse nationalities and social classes. Among them are a mixed-race American painter aspiring to greater achievements, an Algerian coffee-seller, a young boy bravely journeying alone, a female physiology student who observes classic signs of disease in a teenage girl in her car, and married workmen who enjoy a unique partnership. Quietly, an anarchist on board weighs the right moment to strike. Always balancing safety with keeping on schedule, crewmen feel pressured to make up any lost time. The pacing ramps up further midway through, the atmosphere tense. Donoghue's particular forte lies in showing how confined circumstances shape interactions. Her characterization is a marvel as she dexterously illustrates people's outward appearances and innermost desires. In her hands, the novel's long-ago setting becomes an exciting place buzzing with fresh life and technological ideas on the cusp of a new century, even as horror strikes." This program will be provided by the Davidson library staff. Information about this Group The History and Historical Fiction Book Club meets monthly to discuss Fiction and Nonfiction titles. How to Join an Online ProgramThis event takes place on Zoom. Please register by 9:00 am the morning of the event. You’ll receive an email with a secure Zoom link with a reminder about the meeting.Looking for more technology resources? Check out this list!

events.title: Book Club Discussion - Six Days in Bombay
events.description: Want to connect with others over the love of reading? Join our book club to discuss Alka Joshi's Six Days in Bombay. This title should be on shelves and ready to borrow approximately 5 weeks prior to the discussion date. Check with a staff member if you have questions on how to access a copy.Book Description"When renowned painter Mira Novak arrives at Wadia hospital in Bombay after a miscarriage, she's expected to make a quick recovery, and her nurse, Sona, is excited to learn more about the vivacious artist who shares her half-Indian identity. Sona, yearning for a larger life, finds herself carried away by Mira's stories of her travels and exploits and is shocked by accounts of the many lovers the painter has left scattered throughout Europe. When Mira dies quite suddenly and mysteriously, Sona falls under suspicion, and her quiet life is upended. The key to proving Sona's innocence may lie in a cryptic note and four paintings Mira left in her care, sending the young woman on a mission to visit the painter's former friends and lovers across a tumultuous Europe teetering toward war. On the precipice of discovering her own identity, Sona learns that the painter's charming facade hid a far more complicated, troubled soul. "--Provided by publisher.

events.description: East Point Library is excited to launch its first tween book club! Join us as we launch our very first Tween Book Club! Starting now, tweens ages 8-13 are invited to check out our first book selection: "Pippa Park Raises Her Game" by Erin Yun. At Lakeview, Pippa juggles old and new friends, an unrequited crush, and the pressure to perform academically and athletically while keeping her past and her family's laundromat a secret from her elite new classmates—a fun, feel-good story about friendship, basketball, and finding your confidence. The East Point Library has copies available in paperback, or you can check out this book as a downloadable audiobook and an eBook. Whether you love to read, want to make new friends, or are looking for a fun after-school activity, our Tween Book Club is a great way to connect with other book lovers and discover new stories together. Mark your calendars—our very first book club get-together is happening on January 28th at 4:00 pm! I can’t wait to chat about this book with you!

events.title: Virtual Next Chapter Book Club: Top Story
events.description: You're invited to join the Saint Paul Public Library's Next Chapter Book Club as we read Top Story by Kelly Yang. Since the fall of 2016, Saint Paul Public Library has been a Next Chapter Book Club affiliate. Next Chapter Book Club offers community-based book clubs for adolescents and adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities. Our members (including some who cannot read) love the way books transport them to different worlds where they meet interesting characters and learn about exciting new things. Taking that journey with a group of friends makes it even more delightful and fun. Join us online (click this link to connect to the virtual book club) Wednesdays 5-6 pm until we reach the end of the book. Estimated end date in March. Contact Erin at erin.zolotukhin-ridgway@ci.stpaul.mn.us with questions. This book will be shared online during book club.

events.title: Mystery Book Club: Assassins Anonymous by Rob Hart
events.description: Join us on the fourth Wednesday each month to discuss a mystery book!---This month's title is Assassins Anonymous by Rob Hart.Mark was the most dangerous killer-for-hire in the world. But after learning the hard way that his life's work made him more monster than man, he left all of that behind, and joined a twelve-step group for reformed killers. When Mark is viciously attacked by an unknown assailant, he is forced on the run. From New York to Singapore to London, he chases after clues while dodging attacks and trying to solve the puzzle of who's after him. All without killing anyone. Or getting himself killed. For an assassin, Mark learns, nonviolence is a real hassle.

events.title: DAISY’s Deep Reads Book Club
events.description: In partnership with Creative Mental Wellness, DAISY’s Deep Reads is an in-person book club where mental health meets the magic of books. Each month, we’ll explore a new book that dives into topics like mental wellness, behavioral health, trauma, resilience, or substance use. This isn’t just about reading—it’s about reflecting, connecting, and healing within our community. Whether it’s a memoir, insightful guide, or narrative nonfiction, each selection is carefully chosen to spark thoughtful conversation and inspire personal growth. 💬 Why Join a Mental Health-Focused Book Club?📚 Mental Health Benefits of Reading: Get out of your own head. Books offer an escape from intrusive thoughts and chronic stress.Diminish rumination. Stories help redirect negative thought patterns and create space for new perspectives.Take a digital detox. Reading is a healthy break from social media, doomscrolling, and screen fatigue. 👥 Mental Health Benefits of In-Person Connection: Combat loneliness. Group discussion nurtures a sense of belonging and shared experience.Promote empathy. Hearing others’ insights fosters understanding and emotional intelligence.Reduce stigma. Talking about mental health through literature creates a safe, open space for real conversation.

events.title: Virtual Author Talk: Liz Moore
events.description: We are thrilled to welcome Liz Moore to discuss her latest novel, The God of the Woods, an instant New York Times bestseller and one of NPR’s 2024 “Books We Love.” Set in 1975, the story begins with the disappearance of thirteen-year-old Barbara Van Laar, daughter of the family that owns a summer camp where another Van Laar child vanished years earlier. As the search unfolds, Moore weaves a gripping tale of secrets, family legacy, and community tensions. Her most ambitious work yet, The God of the Woods delivers a rich, multi-layered drama full of twists and haunting mysteries. Join us for this conversation with Liz Moore as we explore her unforgettable story.This program is part of Santa Clara County Library District's celebration of Silicon Valley Reads. --- The free, virtual series is open to the public and takes place two to three times a month. All author talks will include the opportunity to ask the author questions. Click here for a complete list of upcoming events in this series. A link for this event will be sent approximately 24 hours before the event. Participants who register within 24 hours of the event will receive a single email containing the link to the program. This program will be recorded and posted here after the event and will only be available for viewing for a limited time. --- The Santa Clara County Library District is proud to present a virtual monthly author talk series featuring bestselling, award-winning, and highly acclaimed authors from around the world. The featured writers and thought leaders will cover a wide range of fiction and nonfiction genres. ---For accessibility accommodations (ex. events.title: Kobetich Book Club
events.description: Join us at Kobetich Branch to discuss a new book each month. This month we will be reading West with Giraffes by Lynda Rutledge. Please note our new meeting time of 4-5pm starting in January. An emotional, rousing novel inspired by the incredible true story of two giraffes who made headlines and won the hearts of Depression-era America. “Few true friends have I known and two were giraffes…” Woodrow Wilson Nickel, age 105, feels his life ebbing away. But when he learns giraffes are going extinct, he finds himself recalling the unforgettable experience he cannot take to his grave. It’s 1938. The Great Depression lingers. Hitler is threatening Europe, and world-weary Americans long for wonder. They find it in two giraffes who miraculously survive a hurricane while crossing the Atlantic. What follows is a twelve-day road trip in a custom truck to deliver Southern California’s first giraffes to the San Diego Zoo. Behind the wheel is the young Dust Bowl rowdy Woodrow. Inspired by true events, the tale weaves real-life figures with fictional ones, including the world’s first female zoo director, a crusty old man with a past, a young female photographer with a secret, and assorted reprobates as spotty as the giraffes. Part adventure, part historical saga, and part coming-of-age love story, West with Giraffes explores what it means to be changed by the grace of animals, the kindness of strangers, the passing of time, and a story told before it’s too late. The book is available for check out at the Kobetich circulation desk. The Kobetich Book Club meets on the last Wednesday of the month. New members are always welcome! Please call Kobetich library staff at 253-280-2921 for assistance with locating or reserving a copy.

events.title: Melinda Myers Webinar: Past, Present & Future of Mitchell Park and its Conservatory, the Domes
events.description: The Mitchell Park Horticultural Conservatory, also known as the Domes, is a one-of-a-kind horticultural oasis. It features three dome-like structures housing over 1,800 permanent plant species from around the world and several changing floral exhibits throughout the year. Not to mention it’s a mathematical marvel of mid-century architecture. Join Christa Beall Diefenbach, Chief Executive Officer for the Milwaukee Domes Alliance, for an overview of the conservatory’s past, present and big plans for the future. Horticulturist and author Melinda Myers will follow with some insights and highlights of some of the unique plants and collections. Register for this FREE webinar at: https://www.melindamyers.com/about-melinda/upcoming-appearances*Hosted by: Milwaukee Public Library About Melinda MyersMelinda Myers has written more than 20 gardening books, including the Midwest Gardener’s Handbook, 2nd Edition and Small Space Gardening. She hosts The Great Courses “How to Grow Anything” streaming courses and the nationally syndicated Melinda’s Garden Moment radio program. Myers is also a columnist and contributing editor for Birds & Blooms magazine and writes and nationally syndicated weekly garden column. Before her current media work, Melinda hosted “The Plant Doctor” radio show on WTMJ 620 AM for over 20 years as well as 7 seasons of “Great Lakes Gardener” on PBS. She has a master’s degree in horticulture and was a horticulture instructor with tenure. She was also recently inducted into the National Association for Garden Communicators Hall of Fame.Melinda’s website is www.MelindaMyers.com where you can find gardening videos, gardening tips and information, monthly garden checklists, and more.

events.title: Book Clubs of EPL: Convenience Store Woman
events.description: Love reading? Love to talk about books you've read? Come join us for lively discussions on all types of fiction and non-fiction. We'll feature different titles and authors each month. Come and share your impressions, thoughts and interpretations of a book we have all read.This month we will be reading Convenience Store Woman by Sayaka Murata.Convenience Store Woman is the heartwarming and surprising story of thirty-six-year-old Tokyo resident Keiko Furukura. Keiko has never fit in, neither in her family, nor in school, but when at the age of eighteen she begins working at the Hiiromachi branch of "Smile Mart," she finds peace and purpose in her life. In the store, unlike anywhere else, she understands the rules of social interaction--many are laid out line by line in the store's manual--and she does her best to copy the dress, mannerisms, and speech of her colleagues, playing the part of a "normal" person excellently, more or less. Managers come and go, but Keiko stays at the store for eighteen years. It's almost hard to tell where the store ends and she begins. Keiko is very happy, but the people close to her, from her family to her coworkers, increasingly pressure her to find a husband, and to start a proper career, prompting her to take desperate action... A brilliant depiction of an unusual psyche and a world hidden from view, Convenience Store Woman is an ironic and sharp-eyed look at contemporary work culture and the pressures to conform, as well as a charming and completely fresh portrait of an unforgettable heroine.
